descript.abstract: Layer identifies emergency shelters throughout St Vincent and the Grenadines, which are typically church buildings, schools and other suitable structures. The attribute table was completed using the 2011 Emergency shelter capacity and amenities list provided by the National Emergency Management Organization (NEMO). 13 of the shelters did not have emergency capacity data. These values are included as "-9999".
descript.purpose: Developed to locate and understand the capacity of the emergency shelter infrastructure in St Vincent and the Grenadines. This information will help inform the Nature Conservancy's AWE project. Scientists around the world agree that climate change is indisputable. Impacts, including rising sea levels, increased storm intensity, warming temperatures and acidifying waters, dying coral reefs, shifting fish stocks, and incidence of flooding and drought, are already being felt, and are expected to continue and increase for decades to come. Nature holds some of the world’s best and most practical solutions to climate change, solutions that keep nature and people healthy, safe, and secure. The goal of At the Water’s Edge (AWE) is to demonstrate that governments and people in vulnerable coastal communities in Grenada and St Vincent and the Grenadines (SVG) can enhance their resilience to climate change by protecting, restoring and effectively managing their marine and coastal ecosystems (also known as ecosystem-based adaptation or EBA) and strengthening local capacity for adaptation.
